questions.text: Which of the following is not an off-label use of risperidone?
questions.solution:

Explanation:

  • Mania is a state of elevated mood, energy, and activity levels and may include symptoms such as grandiosity, reduced need for sleep, racing thoughts, and increased risk-taking behavior.
  • Depression is a mood disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, loss of interest or pleasure in activities, and impairments in daily functioning.

 

Risperidone

questions.text: Which of the below statements is accurate regarding disulfiram?

choices.text: When used with alcohol, the patients feel drowsy, with chest discomfort and respiratory depression
It can be initiated even in minimally motivated persons
Its action persists up to 2-3 days after stopping the drug

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - When used with alcohol, the patients feel drowsy, with chest discomfort and respiratory depression

  • Disulfiram works by inhibiting the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase, which is responsible for alcohol metabolism.
  • When alcohol is consumed while on disulfiram therapy, there is an accumulation of acetaldehyde, a toxic metabolite, leading to unpleasant symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and headache.
  • It may last for 14 days after the last dose of disulfiram.

It is an anti-craving drug (Option B): Disulfiram is not considered an anti-craving drug. It works by causing an aversive reaction to alcohol, discouraging drinking, rather than directly addressing alcohol cravings or the psychological aspects of dependence.

It can be initiated even in minimally motivated persons (Option C): Disulfiram is typically initiated in individuals who are highly motivated to quit drinking, as they need to understand the risks of alcohol consumption while on the medication. It is not suitable for minimally motivated individuals.

Its action persists up to 2-3 days after stopping the drug (Option D): The effects of disulfiram can last 7-14 days after discontinuation. Patients should be counseled about this extended effect to prevent disulfiram-alcohol reactions.

questions.text: What is the probable cause for the development of respiratory difficulty in a patient who received intravenous morphine for pain relief after a road traffic accident, considering the presence of pelvic fracture and head trauma?

choices.text: CO₂ retention due to opioid use

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - CO₂ retention due to opioid use

  • Opioids like morphine depress the respiratory system by acting on the brainstem's respiratory centers, reducing the respiratory drive and sensitivity to CO₂ levels. In this case, morphine likely caused respiratory depression, leading to hypoventilation and CO₂ retention, contributing to the patient's respiratory difficulty.

Head injury is contraindicated in morphine usage:

  • Morphine retains CO2, increasing ICP which adds to already increased ICP
  • Therapeutic doses can result in marked respiratory depression
  • Interferes with the assessment of progress by causing miosis, vomiting & altered mentation

Pelvic Fracture (Option A): While a pelvic fracture can cause significant pain and may lead to complications like internal bleeding or organ injury, it is unlikely to cause respiratory difficulty in this case directly. The onset of respiratory difficulty shortly after the administration of IV morphine points more toward a drug-related cause.

Cerebral Edema (Option C), which occurs due to brain swelling from trauma, is unlikely to be the cause of respiratory difficulty following IV morphine administration. It typically presents with other neurological signs, such as altered consciousness or increased intracranial pressure, rather than respiratory symptoms alone.

Pulmonary Embolism (Option D): While pulmonary embolism can cause sudden respiratory distress, it is less probable here, given that the respiratory difficulty occurred soon after IV morphine administration. The timing and known opioid side effects make CO₂ retention due to opioid use a more likely explanation.

questions.text: For a patient who has commenced lithium therapy, which of the following adverse effects should they be instructed to be vigilant for in order to detect any signs of toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Vertigo and Diarrhoea

  • Lithium is commonly prescribed for treating bipolar disorder. While effective in managing mood symptoms, it is crucial to monitor for potential side effects, including signs of lithium toxicity.
  • A key feature of lithium toxicity is the occurrence of neurological and gastrointestinal disturbances. Vertigo, a spinning or dizzy sensation, is one such neurological symptom, while diarrhea is a frequent gastrointestinal issue associated with toxicity.

Side effects of Lithium therapy:

  • Initial Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, and mild diarrhea; minimized by starting with lower doses.
  • Common Effects:
    • Thirst and polyuria (excessive urination) in most patients.
    • Fine tremors may occur even at therapeutic levels.
  • CNS Toxicity (as plasma levels rise): Coarse tremors, dizziness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, mental confusion, slurred speech, hyperreflexia.
  • Overdose (Plasma concentration > 2 mEq/L): Symptoms include muscle twitching, drowsiness, delirium, coma, convulsions, severe vomiting, diarrhea, albuminuria, hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Monitoring: Regular monitoring of lithium levels, kidney function, and electrolytes is essential.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants causes the least sexual dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Mirtazapine:

Mirtazapine, an atypical antidepressant, is generally associated with a lower incidence of sexual dysfunction compared to other antidepressants. It works by enhancing the release of norepinephrine and serotonin.

  • Unlike selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like fluoxetine (Option A) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) like venlafaxine (Option B), mirtazapine (Option C) has a different mechanism of action.
  • It is generally linked to a lower risk of sexual dysfunction compared to SSRIs and SNRIs.
  • This is because it does not directly inhibit serotonin reuptake, which is believed to contribute to sexual side effects.
  • Instead, mirtazapine primarily works by antagonizing certain serotonin and alpha-2 receptors, which increases the release of norepinephrine and serotonin.

questions.text: A psychiatric patient was started on lithium for the management of bipolar disorder. To monitor the blood lithium levels, at what time interval should the blood sample be collected after the administration of lithium tablets?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - After 12 hours

  • Monitoring blood lithium levels is crucial to ensure the therapeutic effectiveness and safety of lithium treatment in patients with bipolar disorder.
  • After taking lithium tablets orally, the drug requires time to be absorbed, distributed, and reach a steady-state concentration in the blood. Consequently, blood samples for monitoring lithium levels are generally taken approximately 12 hours after the last dose.
  • Measuring lithium levels 12 hours after administration provides an accurate assessment of the drug's concentration, enabling healthcare providers to adjust the dosage if necessary.

After 24 hours (Option A): Collecting a blood sample 24 hours after administering lithium may lead to inaccurate lithium level readings. By this time, the drug could have been metabolized and eliminated to a considerable degree, resulting in a sample that no longer reflects the therapeutic concentration.

After 6 hours (Option C): Drawing a blood sample just 6 hours after lithium administration may not provide an accurate measurement of its levels. At this point, the drug may not have reached its peak concentration, and the sample may not accurately reflect the steady-state levels needed for proper monitoring.

Immediately after taking tablets (Option D): Taking a blood sample immediately after administering lithium would not provide an accurate representation of the drug's concentration in the bloodstream. The drug requires time to be absorbed and distributed before it reaches its peak concentration.

questions.text: Which drug is most likely responsible for visual disturbances and contraction of the visual field in a patient who was taking antiepileptics for seizure management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Vigabatrin

  • Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic medication commonly associated with visual disturbances, particularly visual field defects, such as concentric visual field constriction or "tunnel vision."
  • It is primarily used to treat refractory seizures and infantile spasms in patients with epilepsy.
  • However, a significant side effect of vigabatrin is the risk of visual field defects, which can vary in severity, ranging from mild to severe. The mechanism behind this adverse effect involves the drug's irreversible inhibition of the enzyme GABA transaminase, leading to elevated levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the central nervous system.
  • Visual field defects caused by vigabatrin are usually bilateral and symmetrical, and they may worsen with prolonged use.
  • Regular monitoring of visual fields is essential for patients on vigabatrin to detect any changes early and manage the side effects appropriately.

Anti-epileptic drugs that require ophthalmic monitoring:

Drug

Ophthalmic side effects

Vigabatrin

Significant risk of permanent peripheral visual field defects (visual field constriction) and retinal toxicity.

Topiramate

Potential for acute myopia, secondary angle-closure glaucoma, and visual disturbances such as blurred vision and diplopia.

Phenobarbitone (Option A) is an antiepileptic drug that is not typically associated with visual disturbances or visual field defects. It works through a different mechanism and does not commonly cause visual issues as a side effect.

Ethosuximide (Option C) is mainly used for treating absence seizures. It is not associated with visual disturbances or visual field defects and is not known to cause such side effects.

Levetiracetam (Option D) is an antiepileptic drug generally well-tolerated by patients. While it can cause other side effects like drowsiness, headache, or mood changes, it is not linked to visual disturbances or visual field constriction.

questions.text: Topiramate is used for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome

  • Topiramate is used to treat Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a rare and severe form of epilepsy that typically begins in early childhood and is characterized by seizures that are difficult to control.
  • There is no cure for LGS, and management focuses on controlling seizures and improving quality of life using Topiramate as an anti-epileptic.

Topiramate

MOA
  • Reduces voltage-gated sodium currents in cerebellar granule cells.
  • Activated hyperpolarising potassium current, which enhances GABA-A receptor
  • Limits the activation of AMPA-kainate subtype of glutamate receptors.
  • Modulationof the activity of GABA and glutamate

Uses

  • Focal and primary generalized epilepsy
  • Refractory focal epilepsy
  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS)
  • Prophylaxis of migraine
  • Obesity

Pharmacokinetics

  • 20% is bound to plasma proteins
  • Excreted in urine unchanged with a t1/2 of 24 hours
  • Enzyme activation occurs

Adverse effects

  • Somnolence, weight loss, fatigue, nervousness
  • Renal calculi formation
  • Cognitive impairment

Treatment of acute migraine (Option A) is done using Triptans (sumatriptan, rizatriptan, and eletriptan) and NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen sodium, and aspirin), while Topiramate is used as prophylaxis for migraine headaches.

Prophylaxis of ADHD (Option C) is done using stimulant drugs such as Methylphenidate and amphetamine salts. While Topiramate may have some use in ADHD treatment, it is not a first-line treatment for ADHD prophylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main concern when considering the discharge of a patient who has been treated with Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) for a major depressive episode in the hospital for 4 weeks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Suicidal risk:

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) have been associated with an increased risk of suicide, particularly in the early stages of treatment or during the discontinuation phase. This risk is a significant concern when considering the discharge of a patient, as they may have greater access to the medication and could be at higher risk for self-harm.

Mechanism of Action (MOA) of Tricyclic Antidepressants (TCAs): Inhibition of Reuptake: TCAs primarily work by inhibiting the reuptake of neurotransmitters, serotonin and norepinephrine, into presynaptic nerve terminals. This increases the concentration of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, enhancing their effects.

Antagonism of Receptors: In addition to blocking reuptake, TCAs also interact with various receptors, contributing to their side effects:

  • Histamine receptors: Cause sedation and weight gain.
  • Alpha-adrenergic receptors: Lead to orthostatic hypotension and tachycardia.
  • Muscarinic acetylcholine receptors: Cause anticholinergic side effects, such as dry mouth and constipation.
  • 5HT receptors: weight gain d/t increased appetite

Need for drug monitoring (Option A): Although some medications, including TCAs, may require monitoring in certain situations, routine drug monitoring is not the primary concern for discharge. TDM is typically used for drugs with a narrow therapeutic index or significant drug interactions, which is not the case for TCAs.

ECG monitoring for arrhythmias (Option B): While TCAs can cause cardiac issues like QT prolongation, routine ECG monitoring is not the main focus during discharge. Any necessary ECG assessments would have been addressed earlier in the hospital stay.

Sedation being the side effect (Option D): While sedation is a known side effect of TCAs and should be monitored, the primary concern during discharge is not sedation. More critical factors, such as suicide risk, need to be considered when planning discharge.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes modulation of voltage-gated sodium channels by selectively enhancing slow inactivation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lacosamide

 

Explanation:

Lacosamide selectively enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, inhibiting high-frequency neuronal firing and reducing seizure activity.

 

Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels:

  • Voltage-gated sodium channels play a key role in generating and propagating action potentials in neurons.
  • These channels open in response to membrane depolarization, allowing Na⁺ to flow into the cell, leading to further depolarization.
  • Fast Inactivation Modulators:
    • Phenytoin (Option B)
    • Carbamazepine
  • Slow Inactivation Modulators:
    • Lacosamide

 

Lamotrigine (Option C) primarily affects sodium channels by inhibiting their ability to recover from both fast and slow inactivation.

  • It is not as selective for enhancing slow inactivation, and while it reduces high-frequency firing, its primary action is broader, affecting both types of inactivation.

 

Ethosuximide (Option D) does not act on sodium channels.

  • It primarily targets T-type calcium channels in the thalamus, which are involved in the generation of absence seizures.
  • It does not directly modulate sodium channel inactivation.

questions.text: The parents of a 9-year-old girl have noticed their daughter often staring blankly, which is sometimes associated with chewing movements. There were also complaints of daydreaming and a decline in school performance. During the episodes, she did not have a problem with maintaining posture, nor were there generalised tonic and clonic movements. The child's EEG is given below. Which of the following is a first-line agent to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Sodium valproate

  • The symptoms described (blank staring, chewing movements, daydreaming, and EEG findings) are consistent with absence seizures, a type of generalised seizure.
  • Sodium valproate is a first-line agent for treating absence seizures. It works by increasing the availability of neurotransmitters and stabilizing the electrical activity in the brain.

Absence Seizures:

  • They are generally seen in children aged 5 to 15 years.
  • A classic EEG finding of a 3-Hz spike and wave discharges is found.
  • Ethosuximide is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures. It blocks T-type calcium channels in the thalamus and prevents the firing of action potential to the cortex.
  • Valproate is the DOC in atypical absence seizures.
  • Phenytoin (Option B) and Carbamazepine (Option A) are contraindicated in the Absence seizures.

Clonazepam (Option D) is a benzodiazepine that can be used for seizures, but it is not typically first-line for absence seizures and is usually used in cases of refractory seizures.

questions.text: A patient who is a known addict is brought to the hospital due to intoxication with an unknown substance. An ocular examination shows the following finding. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: This action can be reversed by phenylephrine
It cannot be reversed by levallorphan
It is caused by activation of the Edinger- Westphal nucleus
Tolerance develops due to long-term use

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is caused by activation of the Edinger- Westphal nucleus

Explanation:

  • The question states that the patient was an addict and intoxicated, the image given shows pupil constriction (miosis), which suggests that the patient was intoxicated with opioids.
  • The Edinger-Westphal nucleus in the midbrain is part of this system, controlling pupil constriction and lens accommodation.
  • The Edinger-Westphal pathway is a part of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) pathway, and it plays a central role in the pupillary light reflex and accommodation reflex.

 

  • Opioids such as morphine, fentanyl, and heroin can activate the mu-opioid receptors in the EW nucleus, resulting in the release of acetylcholine (ACh), a neurotransmitter that stimulates the pupillary sphincter muscle.
  • In addition to the EW nucleus, opioids can also activate mu-opioid receptors in other parts of the brainstem, which can further contribute to respiratory depression, sedation, and analgesia.

This action can be reversed by phenylephrine (Option A): Phenylephrine is an alpha-1 adrenergic agonist that causes mydriasis (pupil dilation) by stimulating the sympathetic nervous system. It can dilate the pupils in certain conditions, but it would not reverse miosis caused by opioid intoxication or other parasympathetic activation.

It cannot be reversed by levallorphan (Option B): Levallorphan is an opioid antagonist similar to naloxone, and it can reverse opioid-induced effects such as miosis. However, it is not commonly used in clinical practice because it has a shorter duration of action than naloxone and can cause withdrawal symptoms in individuals who are physically dependent on opioids.

Tolerance develops due to long-term use (Option D): Tolerance can develop with long-term use of opioids, leading to a decrease in the effectiveness of the medication and an increased risk of overdose. However, tolerance alone does not cause overdose; rather, overdose occurs when someone takes too much of the opioi,d and the body is unable to handle the excess.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presented to the psychiatry outpatient department (OPD) exhibiting symptoms of hypomania. She has a previous history of a manic episode. Currently, she is considering pregnancy. Which medication should be avoided due to its high teratogenic potential for the developing fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Valproate

 

Explanation:

  • Valproate (valproic acid) is known to have a high teratogenic potential and should be avoided in women who are planning pregnancy.
  • It is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects (such as spina bifida) and other congenital malformations if used during pregnancy.
  • Valproate (valproic acid) is an anticonvulsant and mood-stabilizing medication primarily used to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder, which is highly teratogenic and is contraindicated in pregnancy and in women of childbearing age.

 

Lithium (Option B) is also associated with some risks, particularly cardiac malformations (like Ebstein's anomaly, about 1 in 1000, a rare congenital heart defect). However, the risk of teratogenicity is lower compared to valproate.

Oxcarbazepine (Option C) is an anticonvulsant medication that is sometimes used to treat bipolar disorder. It is not known to be highly teratogenic, but there is limited data on its safety during pregnancy. It is generally considered to be safer than valproate and lithium.

Olanzapine (Option D) is an atypical antipsychotic that is generally considered to have a lower teratogenic risk compared to mood stabilizers like valproate.

questions.text: What is the etiology of malignant neuroleptic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option. C

  • Antipsychotics: Malignant neuroleptic syndrome is primarily associated with the use of antipsychotic medications, which are used to treat psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Malignant neuroleptic syndrome is a rare but potentially life-threatening adverse reaction to certain antipsychotic medications. It is characterized by symptoms such as severe muscle stiffness, high fever, altered mental status, autonomic dysfunction, and increased levels of creatine phosphokinase (CPK) in the blood. Prompt recognition and discontinuation of the offending medication are essential in managing malignant neuroleptic syndrome.

Incorrect options 

Option A. Antidepressants: Antidepressants are medications used to treat various forms of depression. While certain antidepressants can have an impact on serotonin levels in the brain, they are not typically associated with causing the malignant neuroleptic syndrome. However, in rare cases, a condition known as serotonin syndrome can occur when taking certain antidepressants or combining them with other medications that increase serotonin levels. Serotonin syndrome shares some similarities with MNS but is distinct from it.

Option B. Anxiolytics: Anxiolytics, also known as anti-anxiety medications, are used to treat anxiety disorders and help manage symptoms of anxiety. They generally do not cause the malignant neuroleptic syndrome

Option D. Anti-epileptics: Anti-epileptic drugs are used to treat seizures and epilepsy. While some anti-epileptic medications may have certain side effects, they are not typically associated with causing malignant neuroleptic syndrome.

questions.text: A schizophrenia patient on haoperidol was responding well for last 2 years. Now presented with involuntary mouth and lip movements (perioral dyskinesia), choreiform, and tick-like movements and possible dystonia. What is the probable diagnosis and treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tardive dyskinesia – valbenazine:

Explanation:

  • The scenario is diagnosed as medication-induced Tardive dyskinesia, for which the drug of choice is Valbenazine.

Tardive dyskinesia

Description

A delayed effect (abnormal involuntary movements) of antipsychotics typically occurs until after 6 months of treatment.

Cause

Supersensitization of dopamine (D) receptors due to prolonged exposure to antipsychotic medications.

Manifestations

Abnormal, involuntary movements such as:

  • Lip smacking
  • Chewing
  • Darting, twisting, and protrusion of the tongue (catching fly)
  • Choreiform hand movements (playing piano)
  • Facial grimacing
  • Finger movements and hand clenching

In Severe cases:

  • Torticollis (twisting of neck muscles to one side)
  • Retrocollis (neck extension)
  • Trunk twisting
  • Pelvic thrusting

Management

Prevention: Using antipsychotic medications only when indicated and in the lowest effective doses.

Regular monitoring: Patients taking antipsychotics should be regularly assessed for any signs of abnormal movements.

Treatment:

  • Reducing antipsychotic drugs (or stop if possible)
  • Switching the medication to clozapine (least EPS-causing) or atypical antipsychotics
  • VMAT (Vesicular Monoamine Transporter type 2) receptor inhibitor:
    • Valbenazine (drug of choice)
    • Tetrabenazine- Lesser efficacy, more sedation than Valbenazine

 Incorrect Options:

Option A: Acute dystonia - ropinirole - Acute dystonia (muscle spasms, torticollis, oculogyric crisis) occurs hours–days after starting an antipsychotic. It is treated with anticholinergics (benztropine, diphenhydramine), not dopamine agonists like ropinirole. Ropinirole would worsen psychosis.

Option C: Akathisia – propranolol - Akathisia (subjective restlessness, inability to stay still) is indeed treated with β-blockers (propranolol) or benzodiazepines.But our patient has TD, not akathisia.

Option D: Parkinsonism – benztropine- This patient has abnormal involuntary movements, not rigidity/bradykinesia/tremor, hence, even though benztropine is the drug of choice for drug-induced Parkisonism, it is does not fit the clinical diagnosis for the above mentioned clinical features.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent migraine attacks. She has been using sumatriptan for abortive treatment, but recently developed chest tightness and tingling sensations after its use. She has family history of CAD. She now requests a preventive therapy to reduce the frequency of migraine attacks. Which of the following is the most appropriate choice for migraine prophylaxis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Propranolol:

Explanation:

Sumatriptan is a serotonin (5-HT1B/1D) receptor agonist used for acute migraine treatment but can cause chest tightness and other vasoconstrictive side effects, especially risky in patients with CAD or cardiovascular risk factors. This patient’s chest symptoms and family history of CAD indicate caution with vasoconstrictive agents.

Propranolol:

Class: Non-selective β-blocker.

Role: First-line drug for migraine prophylaxis.

Mechanism: Reduces cortical excitability, stabilises vascular tone, and dampens sympathetic overactivity.

  • Patient has a history of migraine and needs prevention, not acute relief.
  • No direct contraindication to β-blockers is mentioned.
  • Family history of CAD makes β-blockers even more favourable, as they may offer some cardioprotective effect.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Topiramate: Also first-line for migraine prophylaxis. It could still be used, but propranolol is often the first pick when CAD risk exists because it benefits both conditions. Topiramate has more CNS side effects (cognitive slowing, paresthesias) and no cardiac protection.

Option C - Ergotamine: Used in acute migraine treatment, not prophylaxis. It is a potent vasoconstrictor and increases the risk of myocardial ischemia. Hence, it is contraindicated in patients with CAD or significant CAD risk.

Option D - Naratriptan: Used in acute migraine relief, like sumatriptan. It is a vasoconstrictor, contraindicated in CAD and high-risk patients.

Incorrect Options:

questions.text: A patient took a drug for migraine treatment, following which there was numbness, and his hand appeared as below. What is the possible drug that was taken?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dihydroergotamine

Explanation:

  • The patient's numbness and hand discolouration, as shown in the image, suggest treatment with dihydroergotamine for migraine.

Dihydroergotamine

Drug class

Ergot alkaloids

MOA

Partial agonist activity at 5HT1B/1D receptors causes vasoconstriction, reducing migraine-associated inflammation.

Uses

Acute migraine attack

Side effects

  • Peripheral vasoconstriction
    • Manifest as numbness, tingling, and discolouration of the fingers, commonly referred to as Raynaud's phenomenon.
    • Discolouration of fingers - White → Blue→ Red

  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Paradoxical headache and dizziness
  • Flushing
  • Nasal congestion
  • Chest pain
  • Muscle pain

Incorrect Options:

  • Sumatriptan (Option B) is a medication used for the treatment of acute migraine attacks. While it can cause side effects such as tingling or numbness, it is not associated with peripheral vasoconstriction and Raynaud's phenomenon, unlike Dihydroergotamine.
  • Butorphanol (Option C) is an opioid analgesic used for the treatment of pain, including migraines. It is not typically associated with peripheral vasoconstriction and Raynaud's phenomenon.

questions.text: Which medication can be administered to reduce the frequency of future headache episodes in a 26-year-old female patient who experiences one-sided pulsating headaches accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and finds relief in a dimly lit environment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A  - Propranolol

Explanation:

  • The clinical history indicates a migraine headache. Propranolol is commonly used for migraine prophylaxis, with effects typically observed within 4 weeks and sustained with prolonged therapy.

Use of propranolol

Drug of choice
  • Migraine prophylaxis
  • Essential tremors
  • Aortic dissection if they also have hypertension

Other Uses
  • Hypertension-second-line drugs
  • Stable angina
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Thyrotoxicosis
  • Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Improve cardiac output).
  • Myocardial infarction (Ml): Secondary prophylaxis of Ml and myocardial salvage during evolution of Ml (decreases mortality).

 

Acute management of migraine attack

  • CGRP ligand blockers: Eptinezumab, Fremanezumab

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with palpitations, tremors, dry mouth, heart rate 130 bpm, respiratory rate 34/min. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D  - TCA

Explanation:

  • The combination of tachycardia, tremor and anticholinergic sign (dry mouth) suggests an anticholinergic / sympathomimetic toxidrome, which is consistent with tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity
  • Manifestations are:
    • Excitement. delirium and other anticholinergic symptoms as seen in atropine poisoning, followed by muscle spasms, convulsions and coma.
    • Respiration is depressed, body temperature may fall, BP is low, and tachycardia is prominent.
    • ECG changes and ventricular arrhythmias are common.

Treatment:

  • Primarily supportive with gastric lavage, respiratory assistance, fluid infusion, maintenance of BP and body temperature.
  • Acidosis must be corrected by bicarbonate infusion.
  • Diazepam may be injected i.v. to control convulsions and delirium.
  • Most important is the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/ lidocaine may be used.
    • The class IA and IC antiarrhythmics and digoxin themselves depress cardiac conduction; are therefore contraindicated.

Incorrect Options:

  • Lithium (Option A): Can cause tremor but not the anticholinergic dry mouth and marked tachycardia.
  • Opioid (Option B): Causes miosis, sedation and respiratory depression, not tachycardia and dry mouth.
  • Propranolol (Option C): A beta-blocker - would lower heart rate, not cause tachycardia.

questions.text: A patient develops ataxia while taking carbamazepine and erythromycin. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Carbamazepine toxicity

Explanation:

Erythromycin inhibits CYP3A4, the enzyme that metabolizes Carbamazepine, leading to elevated carbamazepine levels and resulting in toxicity, with ataxia being a common symptom.

  • MOA: Inhibits high-frequency neuronal discharges and modulates voltage-gated sodium channels.
  • Uses:
    • Trigeminal neuralgia
    • GTCS (generalized tonic clonic seizures)
    • Partial seizures
    • Bipolar disorder.
  • Interactions:
    • Metabolism of carbamazepine is induced by phenobarbitone, phenytoin, and vice versa.
    • Erythromycin, fluoxetine, and isoniazid inhibit the metabolism of carbamazepine. (Option A)

 

Adverse Effects

Description

Neurotoxicity

Sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, and ataxia

Gastrointestinal Effects

Vomiting and diarrhoea occur with higher doses.

Acute Intoxication

Coma, convulsions, cardiovascular collapse.

Haematological

Agranulocytosis, aplastic anaemia.

Hypersensitivity Reactions

Rashes, photosensitivity, hepatitis, lupus-like syndrome.

Water Retention and Hyponatremia

Due to enhanced antidiuretic hormone (ADH) action, it is more common in the elderly.

Teratogenicity

Increased incidence of minor fetal malformations.

Erythromycin toxicity (Option B) is not the cause, as it rarely causes ataxia. Its main role here is as a CYP3A4 inhibitor, which increases carbamazepine levels and leads to toxicity.

Worsening of the underlying disease (Option C) can cause ataxia, but the timing after starting erythromycin points to a drug interaction, making this less likely.

A separate, unrelated neurological condition (Option D) is unlikely, as the timing with carbamazepine and erythromycin use suggests a drug interaction rather than a new, unrelated diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the medication utilized for the treatment of refractory and intractable rheumatic chorea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D: Sodium valproate

  • Sodium valproate is an antiepileptic medication that is also used for the treatment of various neurological and psychiatric conditions.
  • It has been found to be effective in managing refractory intractable rheumatic chorea, a movement disorder associated with rheumatic fever.
  • Sodium valproate helps to reduce the severity and frequency of abnormal movements seen in chorea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Probenecid- Probenecid is a medication primarily used in the treatment of gout and certain other conditions involving high levels of uric acid. It does not have a specific role in the management of rheumatic chorea.

Option B: Diazepam- Diazepam is a benzodiazepine medication that is commonly used as a muscle relaxant, antianxiety agent, and anticonvulsant. While it may help manage some of the symptoms associated with chorea, it is not considered a primary treatment for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea.

Option C: Haloperidol- Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication primarily used in the treatment of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders. While it may help control certain aspects of chorea, it is not the drug of choice for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is primarily responsible for the condition observed in a 55-year-old male who presents with rigidity, frequent falls, slowness in movements, tremors, and a short stepping gait?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Dopamine

  • The symptoms described are characteristic of Parkinson's disease, which is caused by a deficiency of dopamine in the brain, particularly in the basal ganglia.
  • Dopamine is essential for regulating movement and coordination, and its deficiency leads to the motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.

Primary Parkinson's disease:

  • Idiopathic progressive neurodegenerative disease of dopaminergic neurons in the basal ganglia.
  • Symptoms: rigidity, bradykinesia (slow movement), resting tremors, shuffling gait
  • Treatment:
    • Levodopa is the DOC in Parkinson’s disease > 65 years
    • The drug is converted into dopamine inside the basal ganglia via dopa decarboxylase.
    • Crosses the BBB and replenishes the dopamine level in the CNS
    • Degraded via MAO-B and COMT enzymes.
  • Alternative treatment options:
    • Amantadine is an NMDA antagonist and increases dopamine release.
    • COMT inhibitors (Entacapone, Tolcapone) and MAO inhibitors (Rasagiline, Selegiline): Prevent dopamine degradation.
    • Benztropine: Reduces central cholinergic activity by blocking muscarinic receptors.

GABA (Option A) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter that helps reduce anxiety, stress, and depression. It also plays a role in regulating the pancreas by inhibiting alpha cells and stimulating beta cells.

Acetylcholine (Option B) is an excitatory neurotransmitter that transmits signals from the brain to other parts of the body. Excessive acetylcholine can lead to muscle weakness, fatigue, and cramps.

Serotonin (Option D) is both a neurotransmitter and a hormone. It is primarily involved in regulating the sleep-wake cycle, as well as influencing mood and feelings of happiness.

questions.text: Antidote for opioid poisoning is?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A: Naloxone

  • The antidote for opioid poisoning is naloxone. Naloxone is a specific opioid receptor antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioid overdose. It works by binding to the opioid receptors in the brain, displacing the opioid molecules and reversing the respiratory depression, sedation, and other opioid-related effects.
  • Naloxone is commonly used in emergency situations to restore normal breathing and consciousness in individuals experiencing opioid overdose. It can be administered intravenously, intramuscularly, or intranasally. Naloxone has a rapid onset of action and a relatively short duration, so repeated doses or continuous infusion may be necessary in severe cases.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Pethidine (also known as meperidine): Pethidine is an opioid analgesic. It is not an antidote for opioid poisoning and should not be used for reversing the effects of opioid overdose.

Option C: Flumazenil: Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepine overdose or to reverse the sedative effects of benzodiazepines during anesthesia. It is not effective for reversing the effects of opioid overdose.

Option D: Physostigmine: Physostigmine is a reversible cholinesterase inhibitor primarily used to treat anticholinergic toxicity or overdose. It is not indicated for opioid overdose and is not effective as an opioid antidote.

questions.text: A female patient has been on first-line pharmacological therapy for bipolar disorder for the past 6 months. She has been fasting for the past few days due to religious reasons, and she was presented with seizures, coarse tremors, confusion and weakness of limbs. Which of the following investigations should be done to aid in her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serum lithium levels

Explanation:

Based on her medical history of bipolar disorder and her current presentation and fast condition, she is most likely suffering from Lithium toxicity.

  • Lithium is used as first-line treatment for bipolar disorder.
  • Fasting can significantly affect the lithium levels in the blood, as decreased food intake and altered electrolyte balance can lead to changes in lithium absorption and excretion.
  • Lithium toxicity symptoms:
    • Seizures, coarse tremors, confusion, and weakness of limbs

Grade

Serum lithium (mEq/L)

Symptoms

Mild

1.5 - 2.5

Nausea, vomiting, tremor, fatigue

Moderate

2.5 - 3.5

Confusion, agitation, delirium, tachycardia, hypertonia

Severe

> 3.5

Seizures, hyperthermia, hypotension, Coma
  • Causes:
    • Dose-related toxicity: Taking a higher dose of lithium than prescribed or recommended can increase the risk of toxicity.
    • ﻿﻿Impaired renal function: Lithium is primarily excreted by the kidneys, so any impairment in renal function can lead to reduced clearance of lithium from the body
    • Dehydration or electrolyte imbalances, seen in prolonged fasting, excessive sweating, or gastrointestinal disturbances, can disrupt the balance of lithium in the body and increase the risk of toxicity.
    • ﻿﻿Age and individual factors: Older adults and individuals with certain
    • medical conditions, such as cardiovascular disease, may be more susceptible to lithium

Serum potassium levels (Option A) can help detect hypokalemia or hyperkalemia, which can cause muscle weakness and arrhythmias but are not directly linked to lithium toxicity or fasting-induced seizures.

ECG (Option C) can help evaluate arrhythmias caused by hyperkalemia or other metabolic disturbances, but it does not directly confirm lithium toxicity.

MRI (Option D) could assess structural or neurological causes of seizures but is not a first-line investigation in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: A patient presented with biliary colic to the ER. The intern administered an analgesic, which worsened the pain. Which of the following drugs could be responsible for aggravation of the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Morphine

Explanation:

The drug which is likely to have aggravated the patient’s symptoms is Morphine.

Morphine/opioids are generally not advised for colicky pain due to the following reasons:

  • Morphine constricts the sphincter of Oddi, leading to increased pressure in the common bile duct.
  • Pressure can increase more than tenfold within 15 minutes of morphine administration.
  • Increased pressure may worsen biliary colic symptoms, causing epigastric distress and severe pain.
  • Pethidine can be used as it causes lesser spasms of the sphincter of Oddi.

 

Diclofenac (Option B), which is a non-opioid analgesic such as may be considered an alternative option for pain relief in these patients as it does not cause contraction of the sphincter of Oddi and can provide adequate pain relief.

Nefopam (Option C) is a centrally acting analgesic with muscle relaxant properties and is not known to cause sphincter Oddi contraction. However, it is not typically the first choice for managing biliary colic.

Etoricoxib (Option D) is a selective COX-2 inhibitor that can be considered as an alternative option for pain relief as it does not cause contraction of the sphincter of Oddi.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true?

A. Morphine is used in pulmonary edema

B. Pethidine is used in biliary colic

C. Indomethacin is used for headache

D. Aspirin is used in peptic ulcer disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A, B, and C

A. Morphine used in pulmonary edema: This statement is actually true. Morphine is sometimes used in acute pulmonary edema to relieve anxiety and reduce the sensation of breathlessness. It works by decreasing preload and afterload and providing pain relief. However, it is not the first-line treatment, as diuretics are preferred.

B. Pethidine used in biliary colic: True. Pethidine (also known as meperidine) is commonly used for relieving pain in biliary colic because it does not cause spasm of the sphincter of Oddi (as morphine might), and it helps in reducing pain effectively.

C. Indomethacin is used for headaches: True. Indomethacin, an NSAID, is often used to treat certain types of headaches, including cluster headaches.

D. Aspirin used in peptic ulcer disease: This statement is false. Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcers due to its irritating effect on the gastric mucosa and its ability to inhibit prostaglandins that protect the stomach lining.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs are used for absence seizures?

A. Carbamazepine

B. Valproate

C. Ethosuximide

D. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - B and C only

Valproate and Ethosuximide are commonly used to treat absence seizures.

Absence seizures: Absence seizures, also called petit mal seizures, are a type of generalized seizure that involves a brief loss of consciousness or awareness. These seizures usually last only a few seconds and are marked by a sudden interruption of activity, blank staring, and subtle motor movements like blinking or lip-smacking.

  • Ethosuximide (C) is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures. It blocks T-type calcium channels in the thalamus and prevents the firing of action potential to the cortex.
  • Valproate (B) is the DOC in atypical absence seizures.
  • Phenytoin and Carbamazepine (A) are contraindicated in the absence seizures.

Gabapentin (D) is an antiepileptic drug that is primarily used to treat focal seizures and neuropathic pain. While it may have some efficacy in certain types of generalized seizures, it is not typically considered a first-line treatment for absence seizures.

questions.text: Which of the following is the half-life of lithium in adults?
questions.solution:

It is not metabolized in the body; it remains unchanged in the system.

Excreted unchanged in all body secretions

  • Sweat, saliva and breast milk

questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilizers causes hepatotoxicity and hyperammonemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Valproate

  • Valproate (antiepileptic) causes hepatotoxicity and hyperammonemia.

Adverse Effects of valproate:

  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, and indigestion.
  • Neurological: Tremor, sedation, dizziness, and ataxia.
  • Hepatic: Hepatotoxicity (mainly in children <2 years of age).
  • Hematologic: Thrombocytopenia and other blood dyscrasias.
  • Metabolic: Weight gain, hyperammonemia, and pancreatitis.
  • Teratogenicity: Risk of congenital malformations, such as neural tube defects (spina bifida oculta), if used during pregnancy.
  • Others: Hair loss (alopecia) and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Valproate is a CYP enzyme inhibitor that inhibits CYP2C9, which can lead to increased levels of drugs metabolised by this enzyme, such as phenytoin and warfarin.

Lithium (Option A) can cause adverse effects like tremors, alopecia, acne, weight gain, seizures and sinus node dysfunction, hypothyroidism, ataxia, tinnitus, diarrhea, and seizures, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI), and Ebstein’s anomaly (cardiovascular defect called tricuspid atresia, a teratogenic effect when administered to pregnant women).

Carbamazepine (Option C) can cause hepatotoxicity but does not cause hyperammonemia. It has adverse effects like hepatotoxicity, neurotoxicity (Sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, and ataxia), coma, convulsions, cardiovascular collapse, water retention and hyponatremia, Steven Jones syndrome, agranulocytosis, aplastic anaemia, thrombocytopenia, hypersensitivity reactions and teratogenicity.

Topiramate (Option D) causes impairment of attention, sedation, ataxia, word-finding difficulties, poor memory, weight loss, paresthesias, renal stones. It does not cause hepatotoxicity or hyperammonemia.

questions.text: A patient on fluoxetine was started on a pain control drug for neurotic pain. He developed an episode of syncope after 2 weeks. ECG reveals a QT interval of 477ms. Which of the following is the causative drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Methadone

  • Methadone blocks NMDA receptors and is associated with QT prolongation, which can lead to life-threatening arrhythmias such as torsades de pointes
  • Mechanism: It is a full opioid agonist that works by binding to the same receptors as other opioids, providing similar effects and thereby preventing withdrawal and reducing cravings.
  • Use: It is highly effective for detoxification and long-term maintenance therapy.
  • Advantages: Methadone has a long half-life, which allows for once-daily dosing.
  • Effectiveness: It is considered one of the most effective medications for opioid addiction, especially for individuals with a long history of high-dose opioid use.

Morphine (Option B) is a potent opioid analgesic used for managing severe pain, including acute pain resulting from traumatic injuries like crush injuries. It works by binding to opioid receptors in the brain and spinal cord, altering pain perception. It is the drug of choice for managing severe pain in an emergency. It is not associated with QT prolongation.

Meperidine (Option C), also known as pethidine, is an opioid analgesic. It is the drug of choice in post-anesthesia shivering and involves both opioid receptor activity and effects on the thermoregulatory center in the hypothalamus. It does not cause QT prolongation.

Propoxyphene (Option D) is a methadone analog that was used to treat mild to moderate pain. As mentioned earlier, the U.S. FDA recommended the removal of the drug (trade name: Darvon) from the U.S. market in 2010 due to reports of cardiac toxicity (QRS interval prolongation).

questions.text: Sodium valproate has an inhibitory action at which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - B

  • The “B” label in the above image indicates the mechanism of action of Sodium Valproate (anti-epileptic drug).

Sodium Valproate

Mechanism of Action
  • Sodium Channel Inactivation: Prolongs Na+ channel inactivation in a frequency-dependent manner, similar to phenytoin.

  • Mood Disorders: Valproate is effective in the treatment of mania and bipolar disorder.
  • Panic Attacks: It can be used off-label for the treatment of panic attacks.
  • Migraine Prophylaxis: Valproate is considered a second-line treatment for preventing migraines.
  • Mixed Seizure Syndromes: It is used in conditions such as Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • Severe Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy: Valproate is also used in Dravet syndrome.

Adverse Effects
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, and indigestion.
  • Neurological: Tremor, sedation, dizziness, and ataxia.
  • Hepatic: Hepatotoxicity (mainly in children <2 years of age).
  • Hematologic: Thrombocytopenia and other blood dyscrasias.
  • Metabolic: Weight gain, hyperammonemia, and pancreatitis.
  • Teratogenicity: Risk of congenital malformations, such as neural tube defects (spina bifida oculta), if used during pregnancy.
  • Others: Hair loss (alopecia) and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Drug interactions

Valproate is a CYP enzyme inhibitor that inhibits CYP2C9, which can lead to increased levels of drugs metabolised by this enzyme, such as phenytoin and warfarin

 

A (Option A): Vigabatrin is an antiepileptic drug used for infantile spasms and refractory complex partial seizures. It acts by irreversibly inhibiting GABA transaminase to increase GABA levels in the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used in diabetic neuropathy, post herpetic neuralgia and spinal cord injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Pregabalin

  • Pregabalin can be used in the treatment of diabetic neuropathy, post-herpetic neuralgia and spinal cord injury.
  • It works primarily by binding to a specific subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels in the central nervous system. This binding inhibits the release of several neurotransmitters, including glutamate, norepinephrine, and substance P.

Amitriptyline (Option A) is a TCA (tricyclic antidepressant) commonly used to treat depression and neuropathic pain (post-herpetic neuralgia). It can also be used for migraine and diabetic neuropathy, but not in spinal cord injury.

Phenytoin (Option B) is an antiepileptic medication primarily used to manage and prevent seizures. It is a sodium channel blocker that stabilizes the neuronal membrane by inhibiting the repetitive firing of action potentials. It can also be used in trigeminal neuralgia.

Carbamazepine (Option C) is an anticonvulsant. It inhibits high-frequency neuronal discharges and modulates voltage-gated sodium channels. It can be used in trigeminal neuralgia, GTCS, partial seizures, bipolar disorder.

questions.text: A patient underwent a hysterectomy and was given morphine in the post-operative period and in the ward for pain. She now presents with respiratory depression and pinpoint pupils. What is the drug used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Naloxone

  • Naloxone, an opioid antagonist, is the treatment of choice for reversing opioid overdose in this patient, who shows signs such as respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils, and dizziness, which are consistent with opioid overdose.
  • It works by binding to opioid receptors in the body, blocking the effects of opioids, and rapidly reversing respiratory depression.

Opioid Overdose/ Poisoning

Cause

Clinical, accidental, or suicidal overdose.

Symptoms
  • Unconsiousness/coma
  • Miosis: Pin point pupil
  • Respiratory depression
  • Dry secretion in the eye/mouth
  • Urinary retention
  • Constipation
  • Flaccid muscles
  • Convulsions (in children)

Management

Acute overdose/poisoning: IV Naloxone (Antidote) → Maintenance (Detoxification phase: To prevent withdrawal):

  • Opioids: Buprenorphine, Methadone, Tramadol
  • Non-Opioids- Clonidine, Lofexidine → Abstinence (Prevent relapse):
  • DOC: Oral Naltrexone

Atropine (Option B) is a medication that belongs to the class of anticholinegic drugs. It is primarily used to increase heart rate and treat certain types of bradycardia (slow heart rate). While atropine may be useful in specific situations, such as in the treatment of bradycardia or organophosphate poisoning, it is not the appropriate drug for reversing respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose.

Phentolamine (Option C) is an alpha-adrenergic antagonist medication primarily used for the treatment of high blood pressure, certain types of vasospasm, and to counteract the effects of excessive levels of catecholamines. It is not indicated for reversing respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose.

Physostigmine (Option D) is a cholinesterase inhibitor that increases the levels of acetylcholine in the body. It is primarily used to reverse anticholinergic toxicity and certain types of drug-induced delirium. However, it is not indicated for the reversal of respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose.

questions.text: Which is a rare but very serious side effect of clozapine that requires regular monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Agranulocytosis

  • Clozapine (atypical antipsychotic) is prescribed for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and is associated with a rare but serious side effect, agranulocytosis, which requires regular monitoring.

Adverse effects of Clozapine:

Serious Adverse Effects of Clozapine

Agranulocytosis
  • Rare but life-threatening decrease in white blood cells, requiring weekly monitoring.
  • Discontinue if total leukocyte count < 3000/mm³ or absolute neutrophil count < 2000/mm³.
  • Avoid combining with carbamazepine.
  • Monitoring of agranulocytosis: 1st 6 weeks - weekly; Next 6 months- Fortnightly; After 1 year- Monthly

Seizures
  • Dose-dependent seizure risk. Higher than other atypical antipsychotics.

Cardiac Effects
  • Risk of tachycardia, myocarditis (fatal, within first 6 wks) and dilated cardiomyopathy.

Non-serious Adverse effects of Clozapine

Hypersalivation

  • Known as "wet pillow syndrome" due to muscarinic receptor stimulation.

Metabolic Complications
  • Significant risk of weight gain, hyperglycemia, and dyslipidemia.
  • Associated with increased appetite due to 5-HT2C receptor blockade.

Cataracts
  • Higher risk than other atypical antipsychotics.

Effects on Pregnancy and Breastfeeding
  • Can cause decreased arousal and hypotonia in neonates.
  • C/I during breastfeeding due to the risk of neutropenia, sedation, and seizures in infants.

Renal bleed (Option B): Renal bleeding refers to bleeding within the kidneys or urinary tract. Renal bleeding is not a well-established side effect specifically associated with clozapine.

Hepatomegaly (Option C): Hepatomegaly refers to an enlargement of the liver. While clozapine treatment can cause mild elevations in liver enzymes, significant hepatomegaly is not a common side effect.

Seizures (Option D): Clozapine can lower the seizure threshold, increasing the risk of seizures, particularly at higher doses. Patients with a history of seizures or epilepsy may be more susceptible. If seizures occur, appropriate medical management and dose adjustments may be necessary. However, this is not a serious complication at normal therapeutic levels.

questions.solution:

Venlafaxine (Option B) is an antidepressant that belongs to the class of medications known as selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs). Priapism is a very rare side effect of venlafaxine, but it occurs less frequently compared to other medications.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects is more commonly seen with oxcarbazepine than with carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Hyponatremia

Explanation:

  • While most adverse effects of oxcarbazepine are similar to those of carbamazepine, hyponatremia is more commonly observed with oxcarbazepine.
  • Oxcarbazepine causes SIADH by increasing ADH levels, which enhances kidney water retention, leading to hyponatremia.
  • Carbamazepine can also cause SIADH, but it is generally less potent than oxcarbazepine in this effect.
  • All the remaining options are more prominent with Carbamazepine.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Ethosuximide?

choices.text: Inhibits calcium channels in thalamic neurons

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inhibits calcium channels in thalamic neurons

Explanation:

  • Ethosuximide blocks T-type calcium channels in the thalamus and prevents the firing of action potential to the cortex.
  • By inhibiting these channels, ethosuximide reduces neuronal excitability in the thalamus and helps prevent these abnormal brain wave patterns, thereby controlling the seizures.
  • It is the drug of choice in typical absence seizures.

Incorrect Options:

Enhances GABAergic inhibition (Option A): Drugs like benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam) and barbiturates enhance GABAergic inhibition by increasing GABA receptor activity. Ethosuximide does not primarily act on GABA receptors.

Blocks sodium channels (Option C): Sodium channel blockers (e.g., phenytoin, carbamazepine) are effective for other types of seizures, but ethosuximide does not primarily work by blocking sodium channels.

Increases serotonin levels (Option D): Some antidepressants and antipsychotics modulate serotonin levels, but ethosuximide's mechanism of action is not related to increasing serotonin.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient, after stopping the intake of alcohol, developed whole-body tremors along with vomiting and visual and auditory hallucinations. Which among the following is used to prevent another episode of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chlordiazepoxide:

  • This medication belongs to the benzodiazepine class and is commonly used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms, including tremors, anxiety, agitation, and seizures. It acts by enhancing the inhibitory effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, thereby reducing the excitability of neurons and calming the central nervous system. It is long-acting and self-tapering because of active metabolites.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Clonidine: While clonidine can be used to manage some symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, such as hypertension and agitation, it is not typically used as a first-line agent for preventing the full spectrum of withdrawal symptoms, including tremors, vomiting, and hallucinations.

Option C - Topiramate: Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that has been studied for its potential role in reducing alcohol cravings and promoting abstinence in patients with alcohol dependence. However, it is not primarily used to manage acute alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

Option D - Antabuse: Disulfiram is a medication used to support the treatment of chronic alcoholism by producing an acute sensitivity to alcohol. It works by inhibiting the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to an accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body when alcohol is consumed. However, it is not typically used to manage acute alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female presented with Schizophrenia. Which of the following antipsychotic drugs causes the least weight gain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ziprasidone

Explanation:

  • Ziprasidone is an atypical antipsychotic that is known for having a relatively low risk of causing weight gain compared to other antipsychotics.
  • It has a lower affinity for H1 histamine receptors (which are involved in appetite stimulation) and a high affinity for 5-HT2C receptors.
  • Ziprasidone is often preferred in patients who are concerned about weight gain or who are already overweight or obese.

Chlorpromazine (Option A) is a typical antipsychotic that blocks dopamine D2 receptors to alleviate psychotic symptoms. It carries a risk for metabolic side effects like weight gain, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia.

Clozapine (Option B) is an atypical antipsychotic that primarily works as a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, but it also has significant effects on serotonin receptors (5-HT2A and 5-HT2C). Weight gain is a common side effect of Clozapine.

Olanzapine (Option C) is an atypical antipsychotic that is associated with weight gain and other metabolic side effects.

questions.text: A patient was given an antipsychotic drug, haloperidol and the patient developed acute dystonia. Which is the next best step?

Explanation:

  • Anticholinergic drugs like Benztropine, Diphenhydramine, Benzhexol and Promethazine can be used for treatment.

Condition

Onset

Treatment

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of blurred vision, dizziness, and severe headache after ingesting an unknown quantity of homemade alcohol earlier in the day. On examination, he is disoriented. Laboratory tests reveal severe metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap. Which metabolite is primarily responsible for the toxicity in this case?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Formic acid

 

Explanation:

This patient’s symptoms (blurred vision, dizziness, severe headache, disorientation) and high anion gap metabolic acidosis after ingesting homemade alcohol suggest methanol poisoning. Methanol is metabolized to formic acid (formate), which is the primary metabolite responsible for the toxicity, causing metabolic acidosis, optic neuropathy, and CNS depression. Methanol is the ingested substance, not a metabolite, so formic acid is the correct answer.


 

Methanol:

 

  • Adulteration in Country liquor.
  • Solvent in industrial processes.
  • Antifreeze.

Mechanism of Action
  • Methanol ö Formaldehyde (oxidation by alcohol dehydrogenase).
  • Formaldehyde ö Formic acid (oxidation by aldehyde dehydrogenase).
  • Formic Acid ö Inhibition of Cytochrome c Oxidase ö Cellular Hypoxia and Metabolic Acidosis.

Features of Toxicity
  • CNS: Headache, dizziness, confusion, ataxia, seizures
  • Ocular: Blurred ("snowfield" vision).
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, fruity breath and abdominal pain
  • Metabolic: Severe metabolic acidosis, elevated anion gap

Treatment

Mnemonic: SHAFE

  • Sodium Bicarbonate to correct metabolic acidosis
  • Hemodialysis to remove methanol and its metabolites
  • Antidote: Fomepizole or Ethanol to inhibit ADH
  • Folinic acid or folic acid to enhance formate metabolism.

 

  • Methanol (Option A) is incorrect because methanol itself is not directly toxic; its metabolites (formic acid and formaldehyde) cause the toxicity.

 

  • Formaldehyde (Option C) is incorrect because formaldehyde is an intermediate metabolite but is rapidly converted to formic acid, which is more toxic.

 

  • Acetic Acid (Option D) is incorrect because acetic acid is the metabolic product of ethanol, not methanol, and does not cause significant toxicity.

questions.text: Which anti-epileptic drug is commonly associated with gum hypertrophy and dizziness as side effects?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Phenytoin

 

Explanation:

Phenytoin is a commonly used anti-epileptic drug (AED) that is well known for causing gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) and dizziness as side effects.

  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels, stabilising neuronal membranes and preventing seizures.

Adverse effects of Phenytoin include:

  1. Gum Hypertrophy: Overgrowth of gingival collagen fibres can cause significant dental and oral health issues.
  2. Hirsutism and Acne: Excessive hair growth and acne are common dermatological side effects.
  3. Coarsening of Facial Features: Long-term use can lead to noticeable changes in facial appearance.
  4. Hypersensitivity Reactions: These can manifest as rashes, discoid lupus erythematosus, lymphadenopathy, and neutropenia.
  5. Megaloblastic Anemia: Phenytoin can interfere with folate absorption, leading to anaemia.
  6. Osteomalacia: Bone softening or weakening can occur due to interference with vitamin D metabolism.
  7. Hyperglycemia: Inhibition of insulin release can result in elevated blood sugar levels.
  8. Toxicity: Symptoms of toxicity include diplopia, nystagmus, and ataxia.
  9. During Pregnancy: Fetal hydantoin syndrome is a risk, characterised by hypoplastic phalanges, cleft palate, harelip, and microcephaly.

 

Carbamazepine (Option A) is incorrect because while it causes dizziness and ataxia, it is not associated with gum hypertrophy.

 

Levetiracetam (Option C) is incorrect because it commonly causes irritability and mood changes, but not gum hypertrophy.

 

Topiramate (Option D) is incorrect because it is associated with cognitive slowing, weight loss, and nephrolithiasis, but not gingival hyperplasia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Maximum oral dose of fosphenytoin causes cerebellar degeneration and brain atrophy.
High doses of fosphenytoin cause cardiotoxicity in elderly patients and nephrotoxicity in young patients
The safe dose of phenytoin is 250 mg/kg.
Fosphenytoin is given to all seizure patients in the ER regardless of CNS side effects and hypertension.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) High doses of fosphenytoin cause cardiotoxicity in elderly patients and nephrotoxicity in young patients.

 

Explanation:

  • Fosphenytoin is a water-soluble prodrug of phenytoin used to treat seizures.
  • It is converted to active phenytoin in the body.
  • Fosphenytoin is typically administered intravenously (IV) or intramuscularly (IM) and is preferred over phenytoin in emergency settings due to its better solubility, allowing for faster administration.
  • Toxicity:
    • Symptoms of Acute Overdose:
      • Nystagmus can appear at doses as low as 20 µg/mL.
      • Lethargy and dysarthria manifest at 40 µg/mL.
      • Lethal dose is 2-5 grams in adults.
    • Fosphenytoin carries a black box warning due to its conversion to phenytoin.
    • Exceeding 150 mg of phenytoin equivalents per minute can lead to severe cardiac outcomes, including hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias.
    • Excessive IV infusion (>150 mg phenytoin equivalents per minute) can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, hypotension, and CNS depression.
    • Overdose symptoms include nystagmus, ataxia, and dysarthria. In severe cases, lethargy and coma may occur.
    • Formate and phosphate metabolites can cause metabolic acidosis and hypocalcemia in cases of overdose.
    • Nephrotoxicity in young patients, though rare, may occur due to its systemic effects and renal clearance.

questions.text: What is the appropriate antidote for Benzodiazepine overdose?
questions.solution:

It is a specific antagonist that works by competitively binding to the same receptors in the brain that Benzodiazepines target, effectively reversing their effects. By blocking the receptors, flumazenil can rapidly reverse the sedative and respiratory-depressant effects of Benzodiazepines, potentially preventing life-threatening complications of overdose.

Option C - Barbiturates: Barbiturates are a separate class of drugs that act as central nervous system depressants. They have a different mechanism of action compared to Benzodiazepines, and they are not considered antidotes for Benzodiazepine overdose.

Option D - Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic medication, but it does not function as an antidote for Benzodiazepine overdose. It has a distinct mechanism of action and is used for long-term treatment of anxiety disorders.

Lithium can decrease thyroid hormone levels

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than with carbamazepine?
