questions.text: A child is brought to the clinic with a fever and has been experiencing continuous seizures for the last 30 minutes. The caregivers report no seizure-free intervals during this time. What is the most appropriate immediate action to manage this patient?

choices.text: Manage the fever and wait for seizure to subside
Manage the airway and wait for seizure to subside

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Give midazolam immediately:

  • Giving midazolam immediately is the most appropriate action in the case of continuous seizures. Midazolam is a fast-acting benzodiazepine that can help terminate the seizure activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Manage the fever and wait for seizure to subside: Managing the fever and waiting for the seizure to subside might not be the best option in the case of continuous seizures, as this could lead to prolonged and potentially harmful seizures.

Option C - Give clobazam immediately: Giving clobazam immediately is not the first-line treatment for acute seizure management, especially in the case of continuous seizures.

Option D - Manage the airway and wait for seizure to subside: Managing the airway and waiting for the seizure to subside is important, but providing a medication like midazolam to stop the continuous seizure is usually the preferred initial approach.

questions.text: An elderly patient with dementia is not compliant with oral medications. Which of the following will be beneficial in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Rivastigmine

  • In this scenario, where the patient is not compliant with oral medications, a transdermal Rivastigmine patch can be used as an alternative. Since only the Rivastigmine patch is available in India among the options listed, it would be the most appropriate choice.

Treatment of Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Patient and caregiver education.

Neurotransmitter-based therapies

  • Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors
    • Donepezil
    • Rivastigmine
    • Galantamine
  • N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptor blocker
    • Memantine
  • A common approach to AD drug therapy is to initiate a cholinesterase inhibitor for a patient diagnosed with mild AD dementia and to add memantine when patients enter the moderate stage of the disease.

Therapies targeting amyloid-𝛃

  • Aducanumab
    • MOA: Monoclonal antibody targeting the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide
    • Dosage: Intravenous infusion every 4 weeks (7 infusions in total)
    • Should only be considered for treating MCI (Mild Cognitive Impairment) or early dementia due to AD
    • S/E: Vasogenic cerebral edema, cortical microhemorrhages, and superficial siderosis

Donepezil (Option A) and Galantamine (Option C) are available in both oral and transdermal patch forms, but in India, only the oral forms are accessible, so they are not the answer.

Memantine (Option D): A common approach to Alzheimer's disease drug therapy is to initiate a cholinesterase inhibitor for a patient diagnosed with mild AD dementia and to add memantine when patients enter the moderate stage of the disease. But memantine is available only for oral administration.

questions.text: What is the preferred drug for the treatment of facial nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Prednisolone:

  • The drug of choice for facial nerve palsy, particularly Bell's palsy, is prednisolone (Option C). This medication helps reduce inflammation around the affected facial nerve, leading to improved nerve function and facial muscle recovery.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Acyclovir: Acyclovir is an antiviral medication commonly used to treat viral infections caused by herpes viruses, such as herpes simplex and varicella-zoster. While facial nerve palsy can be caused by herpes zoster (Ramsay Hunt syndrome), acyclovir is not the primary drug of choice for the treatment of facial nerve palsy. The mainstay of treatment for this condition involves addressing inflammation and promoting nerve recovery.

Option B - Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic commonly used to treat various bacterial infections. However, bacterial infections are not a typical cause of facial nerve palsy, and antibiotics like ceftriaxone are not the primary treatment for this condition.

Option D - Naproxen: Naproxen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) commonly used to relieve pain and inflammation. While NSAIDs can help manage pain associated with facial nerve palsy, they do not directly address the underlying inflammation of the facial nerve. Moreover, corticosteroids like prednisolone are more effective in reducing inflammation and improving outcomes in cases of facial nerve palsy.

questions.text: In the case of a newborn delivered by an HIV-positive woman who was not receiving treatment, what is the recommended initial course of treatment to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nevirapine + Zidovudine + Lamivudine 6 weeks:

  • The newborn in the given clinical scenario falls under the high-risk category, and the initiation of presumptive HIV therapy is indicated in this newborn. 
  • Presumptive HIV therapy in this case involves: Zidovudine + lamivudine + (either nevirapine or raltegravir) for 6 weeks. [Raltegravir is indicated in infants at risk of HIV-2 infection].

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nevirapine 6 months: Nevirapine is an antiretroviral medication that can help prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV. However, the recommended duration of nevirapine prophylaxis for newborns is typically 6 weeks, not 6 months. Prolonged use may expose the infant to unnecessary medication and potential side effects.

Option B - Zidovudine 6 weeks: Zidovudine is another antiretroviral drug used to prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV. The standard regimen for newborns involves administering zidovudine for 6 weeks. This regimen has been shown to be effective in reducing the risk of transmission when combined with other preventive measures.

Option D - Nevirapine 6 weeks​​​​​​​​​​​​​​: Nevirapine alone is a commonly used antiretroviral medication for newborns at risk of HIV transmission. The recommended duration of nevirapine prophylaxis is generally 6 weeks. This option can be effective in reducing the risk of transmission when used as part of a comprehensive prevention strategy.

questions.text: In the management of CMV retinitis, which drug is considered the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ganciclovir:

  • Ganciclovir is the drug of choice for CMV retinitis. Ganciclovir and its oral prodrug valganciclovir are potent antiviral medications specifically designed to target CMV infections. They work by inhibiting the replication of CMV DNA. Ganciclovir can be administered intravenously, orally, or through intraocular implants to treat CMV retinitis effectively.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cotrimoxazole: Cotrimoxazole is not the drug of choice for CMV retinitis. It is an antibiotic combination of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim commonly used to treat various bacterial infections and some opportunistic infections, but it is not effective against cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections.

Option B - Valacyclovir: Valacyclovir is an antiviral medication primarily used for the treatment of herpes simplex and herpes zoster infections. However, it is not the drug of choice for CMV retinitis. While valacyclovir is effective against herpes viruses, it does not have the same potency against CMV.

Option C - Tenofovir: Tenofovir is an antiretroviral medication used in the treatment of HIV infection and prevention. While it can have activity against some other viruses, it is not typically used as a first-line treatment for CMV retinitis. Other medications like ganciclovir are more effective against CMV.

questions.text: After undergoing lithium therapy for a year, all of the following adverse effects are visible, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Tardive dyskinesia:

  • Tardive dyskinesia is not typically associated with lithium therapy. Tardive dyskinesia is a movement disorder that can occur as a side effect of certain medications, particularly antipsychotic medications. It involves involuntary and repetitive movements, often involving the face and tongue. This side effect is more commonly associated with antipsychotic drugs rather than lithium.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hypothyroidism: Lithium therapy is associated with the risk of hypothyroidism, which is an underactive thyroid gland. This adverse effect occurs due to the impact of lithium on thyroid function. Regular monitoring of thyroid function is often recommended during lithium treatment.

Option B - Tremors: Tremors, specifically fine hand tremors, are a well-known side effect of lithium therapy. They can occur as a result of the medication's effect on the central nervous system. These tremors are usually dose-dependent and can be managed by adjusting the dosage of lithium.

Option C - Diabetes insipidus: Lithium therapy can lead to the development of diabetes insipidus, which is a condition characterized by excessive thirst and production of large amounts of diluted urine. It occurs due to the impact of lithium on the kidneys' ability to concentrate urine. Regular monitoring of kidney function and hydration status is important during lithium treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) used in the treatment of depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Trazodone:

  • No, trazodone is not an SSRI. It is an atypical antidepressant that primarily functions as a serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor (SARI). While it can be used to treat depression, it is not classified as an SSRI.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fluoxetine: Yes, fluoxetine is an SSRI (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor) that is commonly prescribed for the management of depression. It works by increasing the levels of serotonin in the brain, which can help alleviate symptoms of depression.

Option B - Sertraline: Yes, sertraline is another SSRI that is frequently used to treat depression. Similar to other SSRIs, sertraline enhances serotonin levels in the brain, aiding in the reduction of depressive symptoms.

Option D - Escitalopram: Yes, escitalopram is an SSRI commonly prescribed for the management of depression. It functions by increasing the availability of serotonin in the brain, which can lead to an improvement in mood and reduction of depressive symptoms.

questions.text: Z track technique is used for?

choices.text: Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Administration of long-acting depot antipsychotics: 

  • The Z-track technique is a method used for the administration of certain medications, particularly long-acting depot formulations. It involves pulling the skin and underlying tissue to one side before injecting the medication into a deep muscle, and then releasing the skin after the injection is complete. This technique helps to create a zig-zag or "Z" path for the medication, preventing leakage or tracking of the medication along the injection site.

  • The Z-track technique is specifically used for medications that may cause skin staining or irritation or have a potential for leakage. Long-acting depot antipsychotics, such as haloperidol decanoate or fluphenazine decanoate, are commonly administered using the Z-track technique to ensure proper delivery of the medication into the muscle and minimize skin irritation or discoloration.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Administration of nicotine patches: Nicotine patches are typically applied to the skin using a different technique, usually adhering to the manufacturer's instructions for application.

Option B - Monitoring of carbamazepine therapy: Carbamazepine therapy typically involves monitoring blood levels of the medication and adjusting the dosage as needed but does not require the Z-track technique for administration.

Option D - Monitoring of lithium therapy: Lithium therapy is usually orally administered. Z track is for IM injections.

questions.text: What is the most common side effect of Lamotrigine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Rash:

  • Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic drug that is also used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. It works by stabilizing the activity of nerve cells in the brain that are involved in seizures and mood disorders.

  • The most common side effect of lamotrigine, an antiepileptic and mood-stabilizing medication, is a rash. In clinical trials, approximately 10% of people taking lamotrigine experienced a rash, especially during the initial weeks of treatment. The rash can range from mild to severe, and in rare cases, it can be a sign of a serious allergic reaction such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis, which requires immediate medical attention. Other less common side effects of lamotrigine may include dizziness, headache, double vision, nausea, vomiting, and somnolence (sleepiness).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diplopia: Diplopia or double vision is an uncommon side effect of lamotrigine. It occurs in less than 1% of patients and usually resolves independently or with reduced drug dosage.

Option B - Tremors: Tremors are a rare side effect of lamotrigine. They occur in less than 1% of patients and may be related to the drug dosage. Tremors usually resolve with a reduction in the dose or discontinuation of the drug.

Option C - Neutropenia: Neutropenia, which is a low level of white blood cells called neutrophils, is a rare but potentially serious side effect of lamotrigine. It occurs in less than 1% of patients and can increase the risk of infection. Blood cell counts should be monitored in patients taking lamotrigine, especially during the first few months of treatment.

questions.text:
Chlorpromazine acts on which of the following receptor?

1) D2 and 5-HT2 receptor

2) GABA and beta - adrenergic receptor

3) Muscarinic M1 and alpha - adrenergic receptors

4) H1 receptors
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1, 3 and 4 are correct

Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic medication that acts on multiple receptors in the body. Let's examine each option:

  • (1) D2 and 5-HT2 receptor: Chlorpromazine primarily acts as an antagonist at the D2 dopamine receptors and the 5-HT2 serotonin receptors. By blocking these receptors, chlorpromazine helps to reduce the symptoms of psychosis and has antipsychotic effects.

  • (3) Muscarinic M1 and alpha-adrenergic receptors: Chlorpromazine also exhibits antagonistic effects at the muscarinic M1 receptors and the alpha-adrenergic receptors. Antagonism at muscarinic receptors can lead to side effects such as dry mouth, blurred vision, and constipation. Antagonism at alpha-adrenergic receptors can result in symptoms like orthostatic hypotension (low blood pressure when standing up).

  • (4) H1 receptors: Chlorpromazine also acts as an antagonist at the H1 histamine receptors. Blockade of H1 receptors contributes to the sedative effects of chlorpromazine.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Only 2 is correct: Chlorpromazine does not primarily act on GABA and beta-adrenergic receptors. While it does have some interaction with these receptors, it is not the primary mechanism of action.

Option C - 1 and 2 are correct: While option 1 (D2 and 5-HT2 receptor) is correct, option 2 (GABA and beta-adrenergic receptor) is not accurate. Chlorpromazine's main actions are not related to GABA or beta-adrenergic receptors.

Option D - All are correct: While options 1 and 4 are correct, option 3 (Muscarinic M1 and alpha-adrenergic receptors) is inaccurate. Chlorpromazine does act on these receptors, but it is not the primary focus of its pharmacological effects.

questions.text: Which of the following recently approved medication is used to treat amyotrophic lateral sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Edaravone:

  • Edaravone is a drug that has been approved for the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) in some countries. It is an antioxidant agent that helps to reduce oxidative stress, which is believed to contribute to the progression of ALS. By reducing oxidative damage, Edaravone aims to slow down the decline in physical function in ALS patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Piracetam: Piracetam is a nootropic agent that is commonly used for its cognitive-enhancing effects. It is not approved for the treatment of ALS. While some studies have explored the potential use of piracetam in ALS, the evidence for its effectiveness in treating the disease is limited and inconclusive.

Option C - Dabrafenib: Dabrafenib is a targeted therapy drug that is primarily used for the treatment of certain types of cancers, particularly melanoma. It works by inhibiting specific genetic mutations that drive the growth of cancer cells. Dabrafenib is not approved for the treatment of ALS and is not considered a standard therapy for the condition.

Option D - Trametinib: Trametinib is another targeted therapy drug that is primarily used for the treatment of certain types of cancers, such as melanoma with specific genetic mutations. Like Dabrafenib, Trametinib is not approved for the treatment of ALS and is not considered a standard therapy for the condition.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug of this reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Metoclopramide:

  • Metoclopramide, a dopamine receptor antagonist primarily used for gastrointestinal motility disorders and nausea, can induce extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) due to its central blockade of dopamine receptors, particularly D2 receptors in the basal ganglia. This disruption in dopamine signaling can lead to dystonia, tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia, with characteristic features including grimacing and abnormal posturing.

  • EPS risk increases with higher doses or in susceptible individuals, necessitating close monitoring and consideration of alternative therapies in affected patients, with symptomatic management involving discontinuation of metoclopramide and, if necessary, the use of anticholinergic agents or benzodiazepines.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that is used to treat various conditions, including bradycardia, certain types of poisoning, and as a premedication before surgery. It works by blocking the action of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter in the parasympathetic nervous system. While atropine can cause side effects such as dry mouth, blurred vision, and increased heart rate, it is less commonly associated with grimacing and abnormal posturing.

Option B - Ranitidine: Ranitidine is a medication used to reduce the production of stomach acid and is commonly prescribed for conditions like gastric ulcers and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It belongs to the class of drugs known as H2 blockers. While ranitidine can cause side effects such as headache, dizziness, and gastrointestinal disturbances, it is not typically associated with grimacing and abnormal posturing.

Option D - Domperidone: Domperidone is another medication used to treat nausea and vomiting. It works by blocking dopamine receptors in the gut, which helps to alleviate symptoms. While domperidone is generally well-tolerated, it does not cross the Blood brain barrier and thus is less likely to cause EPS unlike metoclopramide.

questions.text: A bank employee suffering from depression came to AIIMS OPD. He was started on Escitalopram. Which of these adverse effects cannot be explained with escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sialorrhea:

  • Sialorrhea (excessive salivation) cannot be explained with escitalopram.

  • Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) commonly used for the treatment of depression and anxiety disorders. SSRI's can produce decreased saliva production and dryness of the mouth. Therefore sialorrhea would not be explained by escitalopram use..

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams or increased dreaming can be a side effect of escitalopram and other SSRIs. Many individuals experience changes in dreaming patterns, such as more intense or vivid dreams, while taking these medications.

Option C - Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia refers to the difficulty or inability to achieve orgasm. It is a recognized side effect of SSRIs, including escitalopram. SSRIs can interfere with sexual function and may cause sexual side effects such as decreased libido, delayed ejaculation, or difficulty reaching orgasm.

Option D - Nausea: Nausea is a common side effect of escitalopram and other SSRIs, especially during the initial stages of treatment. It may occur in some individuals but usually improves over time or with dose adjustments.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-epileptic drug is least teratogenic during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option D: Levetiracetam-

  • Levetiracetam does not interact with other drugs, is excreted through the kidney, and has rapid onset action. So it is used as the most preferred antiepileptic drug during pregnancy.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Exposure to Phenytoin can result in a complication called fetal hydantoin syndrome.

Option B. Exposure to Valproate can result in fetal Valproate syndrome.

Option C. Carbamazepine has teratogenic effects, such that it can cause developmental delay, growth retardation, and abnormal IQ.

questions.text: Which anti-amoebic medication, when combined with alcohol, may have caused the lady to experience symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and dizziness at a social gathering?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Metronidazole:

  • Metronidazole has a significant interaction with alcohol, which can result in a disulfiram-like reaction.

  • This reaction occurs due to the inhibition of aldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme by metronidazole, leading to an accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed.

  • Acetaldehyde is a toxic metabolite that causes unpleasant symptoms similar to a hangover, including nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, headache, and dizziness.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Nitazoxanide: Nitazoxanide is an anti-parasitic medication used to treat protozoal infections, including amoebiasis. It does not have a documented interaction with alcohol causing a disulfiram-like reaction.

Option C - Paromomycin: Paromomycin is an antibiotic used to treat intestinal infections, including amoebiasis. It does not have a documented interaction with alcohol causing a disulfiram-like reaction.

Option D - Diloxanide: Diloxanide is an anti-amoebic drug used to eliminate the cysts of Entamoeba histolytica from the intestinal tract after acute amoebic colitis. It does not have a documented interaction with alcohol causing a disulfiram-like reaction.

questions.text: Antidote for alprazolam is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Flumazenil:

  • Flumazenil is the correct antidote for alprazolam.

  • It is a specific antagonist for benzodiazepines, including alprazolam.

  • Flumazenil works by competitively binding to the benzodiazepine receptor sites in the brain, reversing the sedative and anxiolytic effects of benzodiazepines.

  • It is used in cases of benzodiazepine overdose or in situations where the reversal of sedation or respiratory depression caused by benzodiazepines is necessary.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Protamine sulfate: Protamine sulfate is not an antidote for alprazolam. It is a medication primarily used as an antidote for heparin, a blood-thinning medication.

Option C - EDTA: EDTA (Ethylene Diamine Tetraacetic Acid) is a chelating agent used to treat heavy metal poisoning. It is not an antidote for alprazolam.

Option D - BAL: BAL (British Anti-Lewisite) , also known as dimercaprol, is a chelating agent used as an antidote for heavy metal poisoning, specifically for arsenic, mercury, and lead. It is not an antidote for alprazolam.

questions.text: Secretion of prolactin is inhibited by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dopamine:

  • Prolactin secretion is primarily inhibited by dopamine, which is released from the hypothalamus. Dopamine acts on the lactotroph cells of the anterior pituitary gland to suppress the synthesis and secretion of prolactin.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Nor-adrenaline: Nor-adrenaline (norepinephrine) does not play a significant role in the direct inhibition of prolactin secretion.

Option C - Adrenaline: Adrenaline (epinephrine) does not have a direct inhibitory effect on prolactin secretion.

Option D - Serotonin: While serotonin can modulate prolactin secretion, its role is generally stimulatory rather than inhibitory. Serotonin stimulates prolactin release under certain physiological conditions, such as during pregnancy and nursing.

questions.text: Anti-depressant drug which is used for smoking cessation is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bupropion: 

  • Bupropion is an antidepressant medication that is also used as a smoking cessation aid. It helps reduce nicotine cravings and withdrawal symptoms, making it easier for individuals to quit smoking.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Venlafaxine: Venlafaxine is an antidepressant medication used primarily for the treatment of major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, and other psychiatric conditions. It is not specifically indicated for smoking cessation.

Option B - Topiramate: Topiramate is an anticonvulsant medication used for the treatment of epilepsy and prevention of migraine headaches. It is not commonly used as a smoking cessation aid.

Option D - Amitriptyline: Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant primarily used for the treatment of depression, neuropathic pain, and other conditions. It is not specifically indicated for smoking cessation.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug has the lowest risk of causing birth defects during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Levetiracetam:

  • Among the options given, levetiracetam is considered the least teratogenic antiepileptic drug in pregnancy. Teratogenicity refers to the ability of a drug to cause malformations or developmental abnormalities in a developing fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Valproate: Valproate is known to have a high teratogenic potential and is associated with an increased risk of major congenital malformations, including neural tube defects and facial abnormalities.

Option B & C - Phenytoin & Carbamazepine:

  • Phenytoin & Carbamazepine are also associated with an increased risk of teratogenic effects. They have been linked to fetal hydantoin syndrome and fetal carbamazepine syndrome, respectively, which can cause a range of developmental abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as an antidote in opioid overdose?
questions.solution:
Correct option A: Naloxone

  • Naloxone sodium is used as an antidote for opioid poisoning cases.
  • It is a competitive blockers of mu/kappa/delta receptors and produces lacrimation, mydriasis, salivation and increases respiration. 

Incorrect options:

Option B. Flumazenil is used as the antidote for Benxodiazepene poisoning.

Option C. Fomepizole is used as an antidote in case of methanol poisoning.

Option D. Pethidine itself is a kind of opioid used for relieving pain. The antidote for pethidine is Naloxone.
